title: World Open snooker: Graeme Dott hammers Shaun Murphy with 'best match-play this season'
text:
Graeme Dott has found some form at the World Open (Picture: Getty Images)

Graeme Dott turned in one of his best performances in recent memory as he thrashed the in-form Shaun Murphy 5-1 in the last 32 of the World Open.

The Scot was behind in the game as Murphy rolled in an 81 in the opening frame, but bounced back impressively, reeling off the next five frames to secure the big win.

Murphy has been in excellent rhythm this season, winning the China Championship and reaching the final of both the International Championship and Shanghai Masters.

However, he was no match for Dott in Yushan, who made breaks of 57, 70 and 62 in the comfortably victory.

Former UK Championship finalist Willie Thorne was clearly impressed by the display, offering his praise to Dott on Twitter.

‘Everybody knows I’m a big Shaun Murphy fan but that’s the best match play snooker I’ve seen this season from Dotty top drawer,’ wrote Thorne.

Everybody knows I’m a big Shaun Murphy fan but that’s the best match play snooker I’ve seen this season from dotty top drawer 👏👏👏👏👏 — Willie Thorne (@TheWillieThorne) October 30, 2019

Advertisement

Advertisement

Dott was pleased with his own display, saying: ‘I played well, it’s nice that my game comes out now and again and I remember how to play.

‘It’s come out more this season and I’ve been relatively consistent this season.

‘That was a really good performance and you have to play like that to beat Shaun, he’s probably the form player.’

The world number 21, Dott, has already been to one quarter-final this season, a run to the last eight at the International Championship, where he was beaten by Murphy.

Having gained a measure of revenge, the 42-year-old will now take on either John Higgins or Mark Davis in the last 16 in Yushan on Thursday.

‘It’s quite an easy one tomorrow, it’s good to get the hard one out of the way,’ Dott joked.

The 2006 world champion has not won a ranking event since the 2007 China Open and only has two to his name over his long career, which dates back to 1994.

However, there appear to be significant signs of life from the Larkhall man who has a great chance to climb the rankings this week, with the two men directly above him, Ryan Day and Gary Wilson both falling at the qualification stage of the World Open.

Advertisement

Advertisement

With Murphy following Ronnie O’Sullivan out of the tournament and defending champion Mark Williams not entering, just five of the world’s top eight remain at the World Open at this early stage – Judd Trump, Mark Selby, Neil Robertson, John Higgins and Mark Allen.
